document.title: Proposal Middle School PI's 2022 and beyond Grouped by standards

0731612104C34F7289E47E013A7DCD0F.description: Natural Selection and Evolution: Describe (1) how adaptation by natural or artificial selection changes the distribution of traits in a population, (2) how the fossil record provides evidence for evolution and common ancestry of diverse life forms on Earth.

EE33F2EFBD604A34A71BCF08B81E7601.description: Inheritance and Variation of Traits: Explain why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation

8873156749304C9BA02B3328EF3650DC.description: Interactions in Ecosystems: Describe the patterns of interactions among organisms in ecosystems, and how changes to an ecosystem affect its community of organisms.

7C8B029D38F84B21B7E28FA385031F56.description: Matter and Energy in Organisms and Ecosystems: Demonstrate how resource availability affects individuals and populations of organisms in an ecosystem.

EC3F5D9C12AA4BC4B6B87E44B09F0DB9.description: Structure and Function: Provide evidence that all living things are made of one or many cells, and explain how the parts of cells contribute to its essential function.

9CCA6DD421354057A475AD7D9FED611A.description: ETS-1 Engineering Design:  Evaluate (1) competing design solutions to determine how well they meet design criteria, (2) how the best characteristics of different designs can be combined to form a more successful solution

CACC589F44F4493E8A52B18734A18459.description: Wave Properties: Describe (1) a simple model for waves that includes how the amplitude of a wave is related to the energy in a wave, (2) that waves are reflected, absorbed or transmitted through various materials.

F6579F86F74445B78EA62B945F778C36.description: Energy Transfer and Conservation of Energy: Develop a model that predicts/describes changes or relationships in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.

E21B21B558F445A49222A29894134D29.description: Forces and Kinematics: Demonstrate (1) that the change in an object’s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object, (2) Newton's Third Law by designing a solution to limit the impact of a collision.

3ECB907B29034D4AA5344BBE75B82487.description: Properties of Matter and Chemical Reactions: Describe the (1) composition of molecules and the properties of substances before and after a chemical reaction has occurred, (2) impact of synthetic materials on society

5B8AF9FEDFA344CAA6EB025608849BF6.description: Global Climate and Human Activities: Construct an argument supported by evidence for (1) how the motions and complex interaction of air masses results in changes in atmospheriIc conditions, (2) how human activities and per-capita consumption of natural resources impact Earth's systems

AE8D2EDB64F44EBAB132D639920A560F.description: Earth’s Systems: Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geological processes change the Earth or model the energy flow that drives the cycling of Earth's materials

D86F3C4BB63E4DC597826A7E161BC49F.description: History of Earth: Analyze and interpret data from rock strata and the fossil record to provide a way to organize Earth’s history

7BBEB4BDE9BF462A93FAA8D91E4A6D37.description: Space Systems: Use models to observe, describe, or predict the [patterns of the apparent] motion of the Sun, Moon, and stars in the sky.

42087058FA224CA19644C7CF7223444F.description: Critically read scientific texts adapted for classroom use to determine the central ideas and/or obtain scientific and/or technical information to describe patterns in and/or evidence about the natural world(s).

70DDB77EC0CB424DB1AEBEFF17E705DF.description: Communicate scientific and/or technical information (e.g., about a proposed object, tool, process, system) in writing and/or through oral presentations.

4E5FA3BDCC6044A5B35203550DDFA80D.description: Scientific Research - Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information

49C587F3FCFE45B5949762B17C4C2252.description: Construct, use and/or present an oral and written argument supported by empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support or refute an explanation or a model for a phenomenon or a solution to a problem.

F5CDFED9A4B04E22AB07C8E629DAE6B0.description: Scientific Communication - Engage in argument from evidence

2BB2B0F237024C0089953F63EFB0D328.description: Apply scientific reasoning to show why the data or evidence is adequate for the explanation or conclusion.

49EF3ACABE56452BB7A5CEA240EDAA85.description: Construct an explanation that includes qualitative or quantitative relationships between variables that predict and/or describe phenomena.

7E3FC936CD214B1F92FF282C5AAFAF29.description: Scientific Solutions - Construct explanations and design solutions

40E0775098CF48998FC4C0C05A3D452B.description: Use mathematical representations to describe and/or support scientific conclusions and design solutions.

389FC69D30FF4BF984CBB65338E1FDCE.description: Computation - Use mathematics and computational thinking

D6153BBD5FE44076BBAA8A0D4E2C5F09.description: Construct, analyze, and/or interpret graphical displays of data and/or large data sets to identify linear and nonlinear relationships.

98E791B654F24BBF81FFD0DE61110B2F.description: Plan an investigation individually and collaboratively, and in the design identify independent and dependent variables and controls, what tools are needed to do the gathering, how measurements will be recorded, and how many data are needed to support a claim.

A20BCBF35D1945CFA2D43E626A1D3BAE.description: Collect and produce data to serve as the basis for evidence to answer scientific questions or test design solutions under a range of conditions.

116F00587827479D85FFEBC7AA4DEE91.description: Experimental Design - Plan and carry out investigations

EA6518178DC843E580B27579E2361DC5.description: Develop and/or use a model to generate data to test ideas about phenomena in natural or designed systems, including those representing inputs and outputs and those at observable scales.

EBDB3492920643A7993336E1DC491E20.description: Develop and/or revise a model to show the relationships among variables, including those that are not observable but predict observable phenomena.

C759E48E65EF4DBCB66B8D859E48B15D.description: Ask questions that can be investigated within the scope of the classroom, outdoor environment, and museums and other public facilities with available resources and, when appropriate, frame a hypothesis based on observations and scientific principles.

FCB0E3D8B272489B97C71C95D04B7799.description: Ask questions that challenge the premise(s) of an argument or the interpretation of a data set.

8F1B2BCF28194CEE9F9A1F7A1100F961.description: Inquiry - Ask questions and define problems
